title.romaji: Kino no Tabi: the Beautiful World

description: Based on a hit light novel series by Keiichi Sigsawa, the philosophical Kino's Journey employs the time-honored motif of the road trip as a vehicle for self-discovery and universal truth. Deeply meditative and cooler than zero, the series follows the existential adventures of the apt marksman Kino along with talking motorcycle Hermes as they travel the world and learn much about themselves in the process. Imaginative, thought-provoking, and sometimes disturbing, Kino's journey is documented in an episodic style with an emphasis on atmosphere rather than action or plot, though still prevalent.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Meta
tags.description: Features fourth wall-breaking references to itself or genre tropes.

tags.name: Motorcycles
tags.description: Prominently features the use of motorcycles.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Achronological Order
tags.description: Chapters or episodes do not occur in chronological order.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Agender
tags.description: Prominently features agender characters.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Rural
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the countryside.

tags.name: Steampunk
tags.description: Prominently features technology and designs inspired by 19th-century industrial steam-powered machinery.

tags.name: Snowscape
tags.description: Prominently or partially set in a snowy environment.

tags.name: Mopeds
tags.description: Prominently features mopeds.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Cannibalism
tags.description: Prominently features the act of consuming another member of the same species as food.

tags.name: Robots
tags.description: Prominently features humanoid machines.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Battle Royale
tags.description: Centers around a fierce group competition, often violent and with only one winner.

tags.name: Aviation
tags.description: Regarding the flying or operation of aircraft.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Tanks
tags.description: Prominently features the use of tanks or other armoured vehicles.

alternative: Mysterious Bishoujo Gun Fighter Rider Kino

node.description:
__Non-anime roles:__  
- Ayana in "GIII-Gamera 3: Iris Kakusei (The Awakening of Irys)"
- Young O-ren Ishii in "Kill Bill vol. 1 - Chapter Three: The Origin of O-Ren Ishii" (movie) 
- Miki in "Jotei" (TV)
- Shiori Kitano in "Battle Royale 2: Revenge"

Not to be confused with the voice actress [Ai Maeda](https://anilist.co/staff/95487/).

Ai Maeda is a Japanese model and actress. Her only voice acting role so far has been that of [Kino](https://anilist.co/character/87/Kino) in the TV animation [Kino no Tabi](https://anilist.co/anime/486/Kinos-Journey/). Her younger sister is actress and songstress [Aki Maeda](https://anilist.co/staff/95645/Aki-Maeda).

**[Blog](http://ameblo.jp/shimokawa-mikuni/)** | **[Twitter](https://twitter.com/mikunituu)**

Mikuni Shimokawa is a pop singer and songwriter. She is best known for her songs used for theme music, particularly the opening and ending themes of [Full Metal Panic!](https://anilist.co/anime/71/Full-Metal-Panic/staff). In addition to her vocal talents, Shimokawa can also play the piano. She's a former member of the girl group Checkicco.

Shimokawa is currently married to [Tsuyoshi Koyama](https://anilist.co/staff/95285/Tsuyoshi-Koyama). The two were wed on Valentine's Day in 2012.

(Source: Wikipedia, edited)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sigsawa)

Keiichi Sigsawa is a Japanese light novel author most notable for his work in [Kino's Journey](https://anilist.co/manga/30399/Kinos-Journey-The-Beautiful-World/), [Allison](https://anilist.co/manga/37086/Allison/), [Lillia and Treize](https://anilist.co/manga/37091/Lillia-to-Treize/), and [Sword Art Online Alternative Gun Gale Online](https://anilist.co/manga/100858/Sword-Art-Online-Alternative-Gun-Gale-Online/). He loves to travel, ride his motorcycle, and is a self-professed gun maniac. He mentions [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1491/Galaxy-Express-999/) and the works of [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/Hayao-Miyazaki) as some of his primary influences.
[Blog](http://kuroboshi.blog34.fc2.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/kuroboshi) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/users/178217)

Got his start in the industry as an animator at [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) in the late '70s. Soon after he switched his focus from animating to directing and storyboarding works himself. As a director Nakamura is often praised for his use of sound, and is known for some of the most notable works of the medium such as [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Kino's Journey](https://anilist.co/anime/486/), and [Ghost Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/2596/) among others.

Following several months of hospitalization, Nakamura passed away on June 29, 2013 due to pancreatic cancer. His death was announced nearly a month later.

__Notable works outside Anime:__

- Breath of Fire IV (Video Game, 2000) (OP Director)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/村井さだゆき)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/tak_tea3)

Animates on rare occasions.
Also is a writer, producer and director for ADV Films and Robotboy Films.

[Twitter 1](https://twitter.com/i/user/1030757741193646080) | [Twitter 2](https://twitter.com/i/user/1467985113997021188) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCtOegRvxx7rZNiIsMyEPIfA) | [Website](https://www.hidetoshiohmori19591105.com/)

After graduation, Oomori moved to Tokyo and began his career at Studio Annapuru in 1981, a small sub-contracting studio founded by [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/). Soon after he left the studio and joined Bebow, a studio ran by [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/). There he mainly worked on mecha shows produced by [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/). He also showed up as an animation director on [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/).

Oomori left Bebow in 1986, and participated in the establishment of Atelier Giga. Around this time he also served as an animation director on [Mobile Suit Gundam: Char's Counterattack](https://anilist.co/anime/87/), one of his best-known works.

In the '90s he was also active in the video game industry. Notably as an animation director on Final Fantasy VII.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/えんどうてつや)

__Date of Birth:__ 1968
__Birthplace:__ Chiba Prefecture, Japan

As a director Nakamura is often praised for his use of sound, and is known for some of the most notable works of the medium such as [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Kino's Journey](https://anilist.co/anime/486/), and [Ghost Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/2596/) among others.

- Breath of Fire IV (Video Game, 2000) (OP Director)

John Ledford is an entrepreneur and leader in the North American anime industry. In 1992, he founded A.D. Vision (ADV), paving the way for other businesses and the exponential growth anime has had within North America. With ADV's success, Ledford turned his sights to making the imaginative world of anime even more accessible with Anime Network's founding, North America’s first cable TV network dedicated to anime. He later partnered with Kadokawa Publishing and began Newtype USA with translated Japanese content and exclusive U.S. material related to all things anime, manga, and model reviews. This endeavor expanded into ADV Manga, which obtained licensing and publishing rights for hundreds of Japanese manga and Korean manhwa.

In 2008, Ledford founded a new anime-focused company called Sentai Filmworks (Sentai). Since its founding, Sentai provides thousands of hours of content across traditional and digital platforms. Sentai’s dedication to bringing captivating stories, including acclaimed titles such as Grave of the Fireflies, Ninja Scroll, and High School of the Dead to audiences, is ongoing.

Ledford’s most recent success is with the 2017 founding of the streaming service HIDIVE. Since launching, HIDIVE is now available via a web browser, mobile devices, gaming platforms, and more. HIDIVE offers new simulcasts every season, an ever-growing collection of dubs, and exclusive titles. The service features DUBCAST SM editions, early access local-language dubs of simulcasts directly produced by HIDIVE, as early as two weeks after the original Japanese broadcast.

For nearly thirty years now, Ledford continues his goal to further the expansion of anime and the Japanese culture as a whole.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/真木太郎)

Tarou Maki is a producer. He graduated from the Department of Law at Waseda University in 1977 and joined Pioneer. In 1997 he founded production studio [Genco](https://anilist.co/studio/79/) and serves today still as its president.
__Nobuhiro Osawa__ is a Japanese producer and animation planner. Currently President of Egg Firm, formerly affiliated with [Genco](https://www.genco.co.jp/).
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐藤辰男)
_Note: Not to be confused with the [animator](https://anilist.co/staff/191872/)._
